Headline: Symbiosis | NISM Research Analyst | VC Lab
Comment: This is BIG trouble. Even more so in professions where maintaining relationships is absolutely vital. Although it does surprise me that people fall for these, paying money to the people who are actually giving you the money.

Headline: Founder, Visualizer, Project Initiator at Call Me
Comment: A few years back while searching for investors for our wire factory, I came across an advertisement asking for potential investible projects. I approached the person and after a few telephone calls he said the UK investor is willing to invest 2 MN pounds into our business. The next day he sends me a SWIFT code for 1 MN pounds. I asked my banker to check the code and verify it. Unfortunately the banker failed miserably. On top of that the banker received telephone calls from the SWIFT transferring bank asking them to pay some transfer charges. I received simultaneous calls from my banker as well as the person with whom I interacted in the first place to get investors. I ended up shelling Rs. 80,000/- by depositing cash in the bank account as requested by this person. My banker too asked me to pay because he was expecting a big deposit through the SWIFT. The entire thing was a hoax / scam. I read many articles here and other social media about hoax, scams, government schemes. I wonder how many of those making these posts have had first hand experience like me.

I find it funny when funds ask money for:
- We need to do the DD, here's our guy. Please pay X,XXX USD to begin with.
- We need you to move your HQ to ABC location, here's our guy. Please pay XX,XXX USD to begin with.
- I also find it to be a grey line when the fund invests and asks for paying a 3-5% success fee billed from a different entity.

Headline: No offense meant, none to be taken. Rabble rouser in Chief !!! Asking the right questions !!
